column1: JOCK           Mary, lassie, will A huv tae wait till           the nicht fur ma answer?
column3: Ye gien me a day           frae last nicht tae think aboot it.
column6: Only           it’s no’ sae easy tae wait as A thocht           it wis when it comes tae daein’t.
column8: But ye’ll jist huv tae pit up           wi’t.
column9: It wis you that said wait.
column11: JOCK           Ye shouldnae be sae hard on a chap,           Mary.
column13: A’m on           needles and peens till A ken whit road           the cat’ll jump.
column14: Ye never ken, Mary,           what’ll happen doon a pit.
column16: A           micht never come up again and ye’d be           sick and sorry if A wis blown tae           kingdom come an’ no’ huv the consolation           o’ kennin’ that ye meant tae huv me.
column17: MARY           It’s nae use, ma boy.
column18: Ye’ll no’ frichten           me that wey.
column19: A’m no’ pit born like you,           but A’ve stayed aside pits a bit ower           lang fur that.
column20: An’ ye ken weel anough           it’s no’ richt tae talk aboot they           things.
column21: A tell’t ye A’d gie ye yer           answer the nicht an’ ye’ll huv tae wait           till the nicht fur it.
column22: A’m no’ gaun back           on ma word.
column23: JOCK           Bit if ye ken whit ye’re gaun tae say           whit wey wull ye no’ say it noo and pit           me oot o’ misery?
column24: MARY           Aye, an’ huv ye gaun aboot tellin’           everybody that aw ye hud tae dae wis           whistle an’ A rushed intae yer airms.
column25: Naw, ma boy, A’m a single wumman yit and           A’m no promised tae nae man.
column26: A’ll tak’           ma ain time tae tell ye whether A’m gaun           tae chinge ma name or no’.
column27: (Breaking off           and looking at the clock.)
column29: Ye’ll be late if ye don’t           hurry up.
column30: JOCK           A don’t care if A am.
column33: Ye ken           ye’ve never missed bein’ in the first           cage doon since ye startet workin’ an’ A           ‘ll no’ hae folk saying ye startet           missin’ it ower me.
column36: Ye’re terrible hard on a chap,           Mary.
column38: If ye hud a’ been as keen on           mairryin’ me as ye think ye are, ye wud           mebbe huv plucked up courage tae ask me           shuner.
column39: JOCK           A only waitet till ma mind wis med up           fur sure.
column40: A wisnae long o’ askin’ ye           whin it wis.           MARY           Then ye’ll jist hae tae wait till mine           is med up.
column41: Whit’s sauce fur the goose is           sauce fur the gander, ye ken.
column42: JOCK           Ye couldnae gie me sae much’s a hint?
column43: Only a lick an’ a promise like?
column44: MARY           Naw, A’m no’ makin’ no promises till A’m           ready.
column45: Ye’re only wastin’ yer time, man,           an riskin’ bein’ late tae.
column46: JOCK           Aw, weel, if A huv tae wait, A’ll jist           huv tae.
column47: MARY           It’ll be stoppin’ time afore ye know it.
column48: JOCK           (he goes towards the door, lifting his           cap from a peg on the way)           Oh aye.
column50: Ye’re only           keepin’ me in suspense, ye teasin’           buddy.
column51: Its mebbe fun to you, but there’s           no’ much fun tae me wi’ you cairryin’ on           like that.
column52: MARY           Ye’ll be late for yer work.
column59: [She hands him the handkerchief of food           and the can, which he slings over his           shoulder by a short strap.
column60: JOCK           Huv ye tied it up weel?
column63: JOCK           Rats wur busy at it yesterday whin A           cam’ to pit my pick doon an look fur ma           dinner.
column64: Bit ye cannae help rats in a pit           an mebbe they’re as hungry as A am.
column65: MARY           Weel, its tied as ticht as A can mak’           it.
column66: Noo look sherp or ye’ll be late.
column68: Dear kens           whit a fix ye’d be in if A wisnae up tae           look efter ye.
column69: JOCK           It’s wi’ thinkin’ o’ you, lass.
column71: MARY           Time anough fur that when yer work’s           dune.
column72: JOCK           (as he opens the door slowly, morn has           broken fully, and a hard grey light           enters the room)           A’ll be hame pretty quick so ye’ll           better be ready.
column73: MARY           A’ll be ready richt anough.
column75: Then we’ll leave it at that.
column77: [Jock goes out, closing the door quietly           after him.
column78: Mary, left alone, begins to           tidy up and prepare the house for the           use of the day.
column79: Soon the door at the           right opens, and Ellen Brown, Jock’s           mother, enters.
column80: She is an old woman, but           not so old as she looks; her spare           figure bears all the marks of a life           that is one continuous struggle against           a hard fate.
column81: She is dressed plainly in           black, with an apron; her head is           covered with a shawl.
column82: Mary, who is at           the window rolling up the broken blind,           starts and turns to her in surprise.
column83: MARY           Why, auntie, ye’re up airly.
column89: A wid a’ liket to a’           seen him afore he went.
column90: MARY           Will A rin efter im?
column95: A thocht A           micht catch ‘im, but A widnae chance           makin’ ‘im late.
column96: He tak’s a pride in           bein’ at the pithead regular for the           first cage gaun doon; he’d be rare an’           mad wi’ me if A brung him back fur           naethin’.
column97: MARY           Why did ye no’ shout on us frae yer           room?
column98: ELLEN           A didnae think o’ that.
column99: MARY           (puzzled by her appearance, decides to           be consoling) Weel, A’m sorry ye left           yer bed fur naethin’, before the room’s           aired tae.
column101: MARY           Weel, sit doon while A mak’ a fire an           get the breakfast ready.
column104: [She moves listlessly to the rocking-           chair, in which she sits passively,           while Mary takes some sticks and paper           from the oven and kneels, making a fire.
column105: MARY           It’s a wee sherp this mornin’ too.
column106: (She           looks up to see Ellen furtively dabbing           her eyes with a clean handkerchief .)
column108: Wull ye no           tell me whit’s the maitter?
column110: MARY           (as she rises and stands by the chair)           Bit there must be somethin’.
column111: Whit wey           did ye get up sae airly?
column112: Ye were soon’           anough asleep when A left ye.
column114: Aye, A wis sleepin’ richt           anough, an’ would to God A hidnae been.
column116: ELLEN           Only an auld wife’s fancy, lass.
column117: MARY           Naw, ye must tell me whit it is.
column118: ELLEN           It wis a dream that made me rise, lass.
column121: A dream’t A wis gaun in a field an’           the grass wis green, greener than life,           an’ there wis coos in it and sheep-no’           dirty, blackened beasts like whit’s           here, bit whit ye wid fancy they wid be           some place whaur there isnae always           smoke.
column122: An’ A walked in the field an’ the           sun wis shinin’ an’ it cam’ dark suddent           an’ A couldnae see the coos nae mair.
column123: There wis thunder an’ it frichtened me           an’ whin A cam’ tae look up again, it           wis rainin’ bluid on ma heid, naethin’           bit bluid, an’ the field ran rid wi’ it.
column126: Aye, the           nichtmare’s no pleasant fur ony yin.
column127: Ye           ett pretty hearty last nicht.
column130: Ye’ll feel           better efter a cup o’ tea.
column131: A’ll shune           huv breakfast on the table noo.
column132: ELLEN           A’ve dream’t yon dream afore, an’ the           last time A dream’t it wis the nicht           afore the big fire in the pit whin           Jock’s faither got ‘imself kill’t.
column133: A’ve           niver dream’t it since that nicht an’           noo it’s come again an’ ma boy’s gaun           oot tae his work an’ me too late to stop           ‘im.
column134: MARY           (moves towards the door)           Mebbe it’s no’ too late.
column137: The           first cage ‘ull be gaun doon lang afore           ye could get there and oor Jock’ll be           in’t.
column138: He’s aye in the first cage, is oor           Jock.
column140: MARY           Oh, why did ye no’ tell me at first?
column141: He’ll be kill’t; he’ll be kill’t.
column142: ELLEN           It’s nae use worryin’ like that.
column143: Jock’s           in God’s hand, lass, same as he is every           day whether A dream or no’.
column144: An’ mebbe           there’s naethin’ to worry ower.
column145: They do           say that there’s naethin’ in dreams.
column146: A           doot it’s gaun against the Almighty tae           tak’ notice o’ a dream.
column147: If He hud meaned           it fur a warnin’ He’d likely have sent           it shuner so as A could a’ kept Jock           frae gaun oot.
column152: ELLEN           A’ll see tae the table.
column154: ELLEN           (as she takes a coarse white cloth from           a drawer, spreads it and proceeds to lay           breakfast.)
column155: Ye’ll hardly mind an accident here will           ye, Mary?
column158: (She has now come to           the fireplace, where she sits in an arm-           chair.)
column159: It’s mony a year sin’ we hud yin           tae speak o’.
column160: A don’t mind o’ hearin’           the alarm bell ringin’ mair than yince,           or mebbe twict since yer uncle wis           kill’t.
column161: That wis somethin’ like a do.
column162: There wis mair than twinty kill’t that           time an’ mebbe forty or mair that wis           hurt.
column163: A’ve heard folks say there his           been bigger accidents in America, but A           don’t tak’ ower much notice o’ they           newspaper tales masel’.
column164: Eh, it micht a’           been yesterday.
column165: MARY           Tell me aboot it, Auntie.
column166: Ye’ve never           tell’t me hoo it happen’t.
column168: Bless the lass, whit’s the use o’           that!
column169: Seems to me we’re baith o’ us a           bit cracket the day.
column170: We’ve got accident           on the brain.
column171: MARY           They ay ring the bell don’t they,           Auntie, when onythin’ gaes wrang?
column173: fur an odd man an’ ‘is laddie nipped           in a roof fall, jist if it’s a big           thing.
column174: Look here, lass, if ye cannae           talk o’ naethin’ bit accidents, ye’d           better shut up.
column176: Whit wi’ ma dream an’ your           worryin’ A don’t know where A am.
column178: Ye never can ken wi’           a coal-pit whin its gaun tae git nesty           an’ a man cannae ay mind whaur he is           whin he’s doon.
column179: ELLEN           They’re watched shairper gaun doon           nooadays an the men ken better nor tae           take risks theirsel’s, the way they           use’t tae in the auld days.
column180: MARY           Aye, but a man that forgets yinst ‘ll           forget yinst too often.
column181: ELLEN           A’ve tell’t ye tae quit bletherin’.
column182: Folks ‘ud think ye hudnae lived aside           pits mair nor a week tae hear ye talk           daft like that.
column183: There’s ay danger and           naebody but a born fool wid say there           wis’nt, but it’ll no’ mend it tae go           thinkin’ aboot it.
column184: There’s coal there           an’ it’s got tae be got and that’s the           first an’ last o’t.
column185: Hae ye pit tea in           the pot?
column187: ELLEN           Ye’d better dae it then.
column188: [Mary puts tea in the tea-pot from a           canister on the mantelshelf As she does           so, a heavy bell rings clangorously.
column190: ELLEN           (quietly and slowly bending her head as           if to a physical blow)           God’s wull be dune.
column193: (Then, as Mary makes for the door.)
column195: MARY           A’m gaun tae the pit tae see whit’s up.
column200: ELLEN           There’ll be plenty fills o’ wimmen there           seein’ whit’s up and keepin’ the men           frae their wark, withoot you gaun an’           helpin’ them tae dae it.
column201: MARY           But we——           ELLEN           Look here ma lass, if oor Jock’s hurt,           oor job’s tae get ‘im weel again.
column202: Rushin’ oot tae the pit-heid ‘ll dae ‘im           nae guid.
column203: It’s only wimmen that huvnae           got husbands and sons doon in the pit           that gaes staunin’ roon faintin’ and           whit nut an’ makin’ a nuisance o’           theirsel’s.
column204: The ithers stays at hame an’           gets things ready.
column205: MARY           We dinnae ken whit tae get ready fur.
column207: MARY           Jock ‘ll mebbe no’ be hurt.
column208: ELLEN           Then we’ll hae wastet oor wark.
column209: MARY           Whit’ll A dae i           ELLEN           A donno that there’s sae much when aw’s           dune.
column211: MARY           Fur——           ELLEN           Hoo dae A ken whit fur?
column212: Yon kettleful           ‘ll dae an’ oor tea will huv tae wait.
column213: MARY           Bit whit can we dae?
column214: Gie me somethin’           tae dae fur mercy’s sake.
column215: A’ll go mad if           A don’t dae somethin’.
column216: A cannae sit           still and wait, and wait, and wait.
column217: ELLEN           Ye’d best be makin’ his bed.
column219: ELLEN           Whit are ye greetin’ fur, lass?
column220: We ken           naethin’ yit, an’ if we did, greetin’           ‘ll no’ mend it.
column221: It’ll dae Jock nae           guid, nae maitter hoo he is, to see ye           slobberin’ whin he comes in.
column222: (Mary dries           her eyes and begins to clear the table.)
column223: Whit are ye daein’ that fur?
column225: A thocht——           ELLEN           A body mun eat.
column227: A tell’t           ye tae gang tae the room and mak’ his           bed.
column229: [Mary goes to the bedroom, closing the           door behind her.
column230: Ellen looks to see it           is shut, and moves rapidly and           purposefully to the door to the street.
column232: The confused murmur           of a distant crowd is heard.
column233: She stands           on the threshold and looks out.
column234: Presently she speaks to some one           approaching but not yet visible.
column236: A middle-aged woman in a drab skirt and           blouse with a shawl thrown over her head           appears breathless at the door; it is a           neighbour, Polly Walker.
column237: POLLY           Ropes slipped and the cage fell doon the           shaft.
column238: Is your’s oot at his wark.
column242: POLLY           We’ll shune ken the warst.
column243: They wis           riggin’ tackle whin A come away.
column244: They’ll           huv them up in nae time.
column247: POLLY (who has come into the room)           Mine’s aw richt-safe in their beds-           sleepin’ aff last nicht’s drink, thank           the Lord.
column248: ELLEN           They must bring him here, Polly, nae           maitter whit he’s like.
column250: A body likes tae dae fur her ain.
column253: ELLEN           Makin’ his bed in case its needet.
column256: ELLEN           No’ if A can help it.
column257: She wantet tae go,           but A widnae huv it.
column258: Ye’ll see things at           a pit-heid efter an accident that’s no           fit fur a young yin.
column259: Waste her life fur           her to be there whin they’re brung up.
column262: A’ve seen           anough, never nae mair if A can help it.
column265: A’d best shut the door, tac, an’           keep oot the row or she’ll be wantin’           tae go.
column266: [She closes the door and takes a chair           at the table.
column268: They cannae sit quiet when they’re           young.
column270: A mind the day when the           pit wis on fire.
column271: A wis only a wee lassie           then, bit ma mither had nae mair sense           nor tae let me oot tae the pit—heid tae           see the bodies brung up.
column273: A dream aboot it tae           this day.
column275: A bit o’ comp’ny comes           handy at a time like this.
column278: It’s a thing ye cannae forget.
column279: Seems as if it wis only the ither day A           heard the bell ringin’ an’ saw ma man           brung up.
column280: He wis that charred A only           kent him by the earrin’s he wore because           his eyes wis weak.
column281: They tell’t me efter           that a rabbit had crossed his road on           the wey tae the pit, but he always wis           obstinate, wis ma Joe an’ he widnae tak’           warnin’ and noo the cage has slipped wi’           ma son in her and A’ll hae nae menfolk           noo.
column282: [The door from the bedroom has been           opening slowly, and Mary listens.
column283: The           others do not see her.
column286: ELLEN           A dream’t the same dream last nicht as           when his faither went.
column287: POLLY           In the midst o’ life we are in death.
column288: There’s no’ a truer word nor that.
column289: ELLEN           No’ when ye live aff coal.
column290: There’s           wimmen keepin’ hoose in the places the           coal goes that pay fur their coal wi’           brass.
column291: We pay a sicht heavier fur it           here.
column292: We pay wi’ the lives o’ men.
column293: POLLY           But it’s a comfort tae think he’ll no’           be burnt.
column294: A cannae staun’ a corp that’s           burnt.
column295: ELLEN           Aye, better broken than burnt.
column296: POLLY           An’ ye’ll huv money in the funeral           Society.
column298: A can gie him a decent burial.
column300: Ye don’t seem tae           care sae much some wey, when ye ken he’s           hud a decent burial.
column301: He’s bin a guid son           tae ye, tae.
column302: ELLEN           Oh aye, he’s a good lad.
column303: He’s mebbe had           his shillin’ on a horse noo and then an’           whiles gone rattin’ on a Sunday mornin’,           but that’s only tae say he’s a man an’           no’ an angel in breeks.
column304: POLLY           It’s mair than A can say about ma lot.
column305: Lazy, drunken, good-for-nothings they           are, faither an’ sons tae.
column306: Come tae           mention’t, it’s a funny thing.
column307: Providence works in its ain way.
column308: If mine           hadnae been on the spree last nicht,           they’d as like as no huv been in the           cage alang wi your boy.
column309: MARY (comes forward into the room)           A’ll awa’ tae the pit noo, auntie.
column311: MARY           A cannae wait, A must ken.
column313: MARY           A cannae sit doon an’ listen tae you twa           talkin’ that way.
column314: First ye’ve got ‘im           kill’t an’ then ye bury ‘im, an’ next           ye’ll be argying whit’s tae go on his           grave-stane an’ aw the time ye don’t sae           much as ken if he’s hurt.
column318: Oh, A don’t know whit ye’re made o’-you           twa.
column319: Ye sit there quiet an’ calm as if           there wis naethin’ the maitter.
column320: ELLEN           We’re auld enough tae ken we cannae dae           nae guid.
column322: Aye,           ELLEN           Weel, there’s a bottle o’ brandy in the           room-press.
column325: It’s harder when ye’re young tae           haud yersel’ in.
column326: It disnae come natural           tae her, no’ bein’ born tae pits like           us.
column327: Her mither mairret a weaver chap in           Dundee an’ brought her up tae mills.
column328: It           tak’s mair than a year or twa tae git           intae the wey o’ pits when ye’re born           strange tae them.
column330: We’re used tae the thocht o’ losin’           oor men suddent.
column331: ELLEN           But she’ll no gae tae the pit-heid if A           can stop her.
column332: We’ll hae tae keep her           mind aff it.
column333: Can ye mind o’ onything           else we micht want?
column335: ELLEN           We micht need linen fur tyin’ up           MARY           A’ll get it.
column340: The doctors were there           afore A come away, and ambulance men tae           wi’ aw they’ll need.
column341: But we’ll huv tae           keep her here whether she likes it or           no’.
column346: A           don’t move sae easy as A used.
column352: Better let her think we’re           ill usin’ her than let her oot tae see           them sichts.
column353: [She turns the key and gives it to Ellen           as she resumes her seat.
column355: (She pockets the key)           Help me tae mak’ talk noo and keep her           mind aff it.
column356: MARY (enters with a bottle)           There’s the brandy.
column358: (A slight pause; the older           women try to make conversation.
column359: First           Polly bobs forward as if about to speak,           but leans back without saying anything;           Ellen does the same.
column360: Mary moves to the           door as Ellen, glancing round for a           subject, lets her eye fall on the brandy           bottle and fires off her remark in time           to arrest Mary’s progress towards the           door.)
column361: A thocht there wis mair nor that           in the bottle, aw the same.
column362: POLLY           It’s a handy thing tae huv aboot the           hoose.
column366: Goes weel wi’ a cup o’ tea,           tae, on a cauld mornin’.
column369: Naw, A don’t think there is, Mary.
column381: POLLY           Dae whit yer auntie tells ye, lassie.
column382: Young folks is that smert nooadays,           there’s nae use tellin’ them onythin’.
column386: (She goes to the door; tries to           open it.)
column390: Whit huv ye           dune wi’ the key?
column391: ELLEN           Look here, lass, A tell’t ye ye widnae           go, an’ A’ve made sure o’t.
column393: Come an’ sit quiet, ravin’ aboot as if           ye were mad.
column394: Ye’ll huv the haunel aff           the door.
column395: MARY           Let me go tae him.
column401: ELLEN           D’ye think A don’t love him, lassie?
column402: Aye           and a sicht better than a bit wean like           you could love him.
column407: He wisnae for gaun till A’d said           the word.
column409: A made him           wait till the nicht.
column410: A sent him tae his           death.
column417: MARY           Why huv ye locked thon door?
column420: A can dae nae           guid here.
column424: [The two women have now faced           each other; there is a violent knocking           at the door.
column427: [Ellen takes the key from her pocket           moves slowly to the door, unlocks it,           and throws it open.
column428: Jock stands on the           threshold, very pale, with his coat           buttoned at the bottom, and only his           right arm thrust into the sleeve.
column434: JOCK           Aye, the doctor’ll be roon’ tae set it           shune.
column435: They’ve anough tae dae first,           though.
column440: There’s           naethin’ tae greet fur, and no’ sae much           in a broken airm tae thank God fur,           neither.
column442: JOCK           Is that aw ye’ve got tae say tae me?
column444: Mebbe it’s ower           afore it startet, but that disnae           maitter.
column445: A’ve come fur ma answer, Mary.
column448: Oh, Jock, Jock, A thocht ye wis kill’t.
column453: JOCK           A’ll awa roon’ an’ see the meenister           aboot pittin’ up the banns when ma           airm’s set.
column454: A’ll be huvin’ some time on           ma hauns.
column455: A think gettin’ mairrit ‘ll           fill in the time beautiful.
column456: CURTAIN           Glasgow: Printed at the University Press           by Robert MacLehose and Co. Ltd.
column457: The           Repertory Theatre was founded between           January and April, 1909, as a direct           effort of Scotsmen in general, and           Glasgow men in particular, to throw off           London’s despotic rule in things           dramatic.
column458: In its first season it produced nine           plays (three altogether new), including           John Galsworthy’s play, “Strife,” which           had just been produced in London.
column459: The second season commenced on September           5th.
column460: In it thirteen plays were produced,           including the first production in           English of a play by the Russian           dramatist, Anton Tchekhov, “The           Seagull,” and six entirely new plays.
column461: In the Spring season, 1910, “Justice,”            produced simultaneously in London,           created an unique record in the history           of the British stage, while astonishing           success attended the production of John           Masefield’s masterpiece, “The Tragedy of           Nan.” In all, seven entirely new plays           were produced.
column462: The Summer season of lighter fare added           six more plays to the record, including           two new ones.
column463: In the fifth season ten           plays were produced, four entirely new.
column464: In the sixth season, Spring, 1911,           fifteen plays were produced, seven           entirely new.
column465: In all seventy-three plays           have been produced, of which about           fifty-five would never have been seen           but for the energies of this Theatre.
